text: it's 20 past so i think we will kick off um hello everyone that's joining me
today from australia a big thank you for joining my session my name is donna edwards and i'm here to
talk to you about the leadership balancing act and how you can achieve success without burning out
about five years ago i was getting really bad jaw pain and i went to the dentist who sent me to
a jaw specialist and they said that i was clenching at night and it was most likely stress related
and that i needed to sleep with a plate on to ease the pain the specialist said to me i can tell you
taipei personality so this is probably never going to go away because you're always going to be stressed out
and you just need to manage it using this very expensive plate
so i accepted my fate i wore it every night for the first few weeks until the pain eased up and then i found
that i only needed to wear it a couple of times a week to keep the pain at bay
i started to recognize when the stress would kick in because my jaw would get sore so it was actually a really good way for
me to start recognizing stress and listening to my body about a year later i changed jobs i
moved from my general manager hr role into a state manager role managing a much smaller development team
of about 25 people it was a much slower pace and within three weeks my jaw completely stopped
hurting and i have never had to wear the plate again three and a half years down the track
now the pace didn't stay like that because of course i made sure things grew and we doubled in size and then i
took on a comment in another state managing a much bigger team
but i've also come close to burnout a couple of times since then but what it taught me was to listen to
my body's stress signs and to learn some tools and some strategies that i can implement to rewind the
burnout but more importantly to prevent it from getting to that stage i do want to acknowledge that this is an
ongoing balancing act and the practical tools and tips that i'm going to share with you today are things that i check myself on and
continue to practice every single month without fail but overall these things that i've
learned have helped me reach a place where i can feel successful feel like i'm adding enough value
achieve the things that i want and take the time to enjoy my life and my work without feeling too stressed
out or feeling too guilty that i'm not doing enough so this talk is for people who feel a
bit overwhelmed with the noise the busyness the distractions and are looking for some tips to make
things easier and clearer it's not for people who are perfectly content in work and life already
um i also might i don't really do a lot of storytelling my talks are more lots of practical tips
and lessons learned so you might want to take some notes i've split this talk into four key areas
the first is putting your own mask on so looking after yourself working
smarter not harder which is tips and tricks to be productive leading like a pro so how to ensure your
team is achieving but dial down some of that noise that teams can really create for you as a leader and finally success in
contentment making sure that you get to enjoy your work and your lives
in order to add value to your company your team the per the people in your personal life
you need to be functioning and be okay i really love the aeroplane example of putting your own mask on first
because if you don't look after yourself how on earth can you help anybody else and how can you be successful a really
easy way to get a sanity check on this is using a wellness wheel i try and do this once a quarter and
this is a check of our mind body heart and soul and you give each area a rating out of ten
where do you want that to be it might not be 10 out of 10 for everything for example gym and exercise for me is
probably about a 5 out of 10 right now and i'd probably like it to be a 7 out of 10. i'm definitely not aiming for a
10 out of 10 because that is never going to happen and it's not that it's not as important to me as some of the other areas
so there's going to be a different importance to different people there's a lot of studies that call out relationships and sleep
as two of the top areas so i definitely suggest having a really clear focus on those
and you can tailor the wheels to suit you so for me i've replaced the spirituality
section with career because career for me is something really important to keep a track on and give myself a bit of a rating of how
i'm progressing and how i'm feeling the other one is travel for me travel is
a really important part of my life it brings me a lot of joy and it also can be a cause of burnout
for me so i like to keep a track of where that's at and a bit of a rating of it um i remember in january i was
i was getting a bit overwhelmed with all of the travel after a trip to chicago and seattle
and i was yeah very much not wanting to do any more travel and now oh my god what i wouldn't give
to be an oslo with a bunch of you guys because i miss travel so much
so whatever works for you tailor this wheel so that it's appropriate but keep a regular track on out
we need to acknowledge that we live in a time where stress worry and anxiety is at the next level
look around in the news today and tell me that you don't feel any level of stress or anxiety at what's going on in
the world 77 of people experience stress that affects their physical health
73 of people experience stress that affects their mental health and 48 of people have trouble sleeping
because of stress we're not alone it's very common looking after our mental health is really
important because we can't help anyone else if we're full of worry and anxiety
and we have this constant stream of things that can cause worry and anxiety that we rarely turn off from
most of you would know about our bodies flight fight and freeze responses and back in the day this would just
happen on occasion when we were getting chased by a lion or whatever but now our brains and bodies are going
in and out of this mode constantly and it's exhausting for our brain and for our bodies
when our emotions spike we can't see the full picture clearly anymore we get an adrenaline boost and we have a
laser focus which helps us outrun the line but this is the opposite to actually what we need in most of today's
situations when we're at our calmest and most relaxed that is when we can think the clearest
and when we can see the full picture i'd like you to take a moment and just ask yourself
how often would you describe yourself as calm at work
i remember the first time i got asked that question i laughed very loudly um because i think the answer was
probably never at the time and then i'd also like you to ask yourself how often would you
describe yourself as calm at home 41 of workers believe that their biggest
barriers to self or family care are feeling distracted and anxious because they're not fully present
we care about so many things and there's so many things to care about but we can't care about everything we
have to try to care less because we only have so many cares to give and we need to be clear about what's
important to us and practice calming techniques to get our bodies and minds used to being calm again
because a lot of us have forgotten how to become there's two key areas for that one is
breathing which you've probably all heard before but the studies show as little as five
deep breaths will really bring your body back to that calmness state so breathing in from your stomach
holding at the top for you know up to 10 seconds and then slowly releasing just doing that five
times resets our body and if we can practice that regularly it reminds our body how to stay calm
the other thing is framing and reframing which we're going to delve into a little bit more later so the beginning of our journey
looking after ourselves and putting ourselves first is self-development and self-awareness developing our emotional intelligence is
the start of a much happier and successful life lots of companies now assess emotional
intelligence when you're applying for a job and also assess emotional intelligence in performance appraisals
so it's becoming you know pretty pretty popular thing but in short emotional intelligence has
an internal and an external component internal is being aware of ourselves so
our abilities our emotions and our behaviors and external is being aware and understanding other
people's abilities emotions and behaviors and when you develop these abilities by
practicing and practicing you're able to not only regulate yourself better but you're able to better control
external situations with conflict resolution and empathy
i've mentioned practicing a few times because all of these things can be learnt and one of the reasons that i love
working in the it industry and have done for nearly 20 years now showing my age is that the majority of
people that i get to work with are super passionate about learning and improving
however i'm sure we've all come across excellent technical people who get to a certain level and seem to think that the
learning stops there people who don't listen to feedback and don't work on their emotional intelligence and social awareness
this is can be referred to as having a fixed mindset being successful and happy in your life
requires a growth mindset and a growth mindset makes you more resilient because you can better cope
with failure and setbacks because you view everything as an opportunity to learn and improve
this image is taken from carol dweck's book mindset and is definitely worth a read if you haven't i will have a resources list on
my final slide which will have all of the books that i mentioned in today's talk the other mindset worth
talking about is abundance versus scarcity mindset i have no doubt that you've all met
someone who won't hire people who are better than them because they feel threatened and want to be the best and i'm sure you've all
unfortunately met a manager who is more focused on protecting their job and then helping their team be
successful they hold on to all of their knowledge afraid to share it these people have a scarcity mindset
deep down they believe that for someone else to succeed they have to fail for someone else to get a promotion it
means that their job must be at risk it's a really sad way to live life because there's so much fear and
resentment on the other hand an abundance mindset is when people realize that we can all
be successful and if we help others be successful it's just a positive thing for us
those leaders that help all of their team succeed and see that it creates new opportunities for both their team
members and also for them as a leader they embrace change and they see it as a new learning opportunity
you can see how the growth mindset can go hand in hand with an abundance mindset
and this can be learned as well maybe your parents have fixed mindsets and you've been brought up to think that way
as well by developing your emotional intelligence and practicing some of the other techniques that we'll talk about
later around reframing and strengths you can change this mindset and let go of all of the fear
when i learn about lopes of control for the first time i was super excited i loved it it made complete sense to me and helped
me realize why some people thought and behaved in certain ways and again it goes hand in hand with emotional intelligence
understanding this helped me regulate my own thoughts and feelings better and being a little bit of a control
freak understanding that internal locus of control gave me the power and control back
pretty much no matter what situation i'm facing was a really empowering and exciting realization
for example my boss yelled at me can i control his behavior no so
reflecting on what i can control helps me i can control how i respond to him yelling at me
i can control whether i choose to stay working for that boss or not i can control whether i choose to talk
to him about his behavior at another time when he's calmed down and understand or i can control whether
i escalate it to hr or to his boss regardless of what happens taking back control of the situation
will make me feel better about it and locus of control goes hand in hand with framing
framing is about recognizing what story our brain is telling us and then being able to change it or
reframe it it's something that takes a bit of practice but it gets easier really quickly and makes a huge
impact on our emotions and stress levels what this isn't is trying to lie to
ourselves because our brain is way too clever for that it doesn't work
when a situation occurs our brain pulls together a story that makes us feel a certain way and the
story is based on past experiences and core beliefs often these stories are negative which is not helpful for us
there's two types of reframing context reframing and content reframing content reframing
is really just how changing the wording of something can change the way our brain or the person receiving the
message feels so instead of saying i can't do that for you you might say what i can do for you is
so it's a really simple technique but it works really well context framing
is like the example on the slide it's when we either reframe a problem into an opportunity
reframe a weakness into a strength or reframe the hurtful actions of others into understanding why they're doing
that instead of being a victim or engaging in fights like the example with my boss yelling at
me a really simple one i catch myself doing all the time is when i say to myself i
have to versus i choose to do something and last weekend
as i was stomping down the staircase towards my study saying to myself i'm super grumpy
realized i was really annoyed and grumpy because i was saying to myself i have to go and practice my ndc talk
today and you know it's a horrible feeling when you're grumpy and annoyed like that
so i recognized it and i reframed it to myself by saying no hang on a second i want to work on my
indie sort nbc talk today because i want it to be good and i'm choosing to do this talk
because i want to add value to the people that i'm going to be talking to and straight away i felt you know
excited and energized and i wanted to do it so just by doing that little reframe can entirely change how you feel about
something reframing is one of the things that takes probably the most repetitive practice but it's definitely worth it
how many of us have read a performance appraisal or any type of feedback and disregarded all the positives and
gone straight to what do we need to improve what are we bad at what are our weaknesses what did
they say about us a lot of perfectionists and achiever type a personalities do this
and we want to be good at everything when i started my mba about 10 years ago
the first unit i did was organizational behaviour and we learned about gallup's strength-based leadership theory
and it was mind-blowing for me probably one of the things that changed my life so much i'd spent my
entire life focusing on what i needed to improve and my weaknesses and this man i spent a lot of my time
especially at work doing things that i didn't enjoy lots of process stuff because the type
of work that people enjoy is based on their strengths makes sense right
so gallant strength spider helps you identify your core three to five strengths and then the focus is on making them
your superpowers countless studies have shown that we're more likely to succeed with our
superpowers than trying to be an all-rounder and trying to be okay or good at everything
it's also much more enjoyable the caveat on this is sure if you're absolutely terrible at
something that you need for your job you need to bring it up to a minimum standard say
but certainly you don't want to be focused on focusing on it all the time and making it trying to make it one of your strengths
so make sure that your day-to-day work is using your core strengths and it will be a lot more fun and you will be a lot
more likely to succeed the self-development of mindset stuff
that we've already been talking about helps us build resilience and deal with stress out of a recent survey of 7 500
employees 67 reported experiencing burnout to some degree
so once again not alone burnout is a state of emotional physical and mental exhaustion where you
feel overwhelmed and emotionally drained it reduces our productivity and energy and it's caused by excessive and
prolonged stress there's some really common work and lifestyle contributors that are listed
on this slide i won't read through them there's also some personality traits that make you prone to burn out
and stress for me i took three out of those four personality boxes so it's no wonder i've had to work hard
on it over the years listening to our body for signs of too much stress can help us
nip burn up burn out in the bud i mentioned my jaw pain it was definitely a stress indicator for me
but now that i've fixed that i have other signs that come up when i'm getting overwhelmed and getting to that
point one of them is my eye starts twitching a little bit it's super annoying and super
weird so i can't ignore it i have to straight away do something to try and try and dial
things back um headaches are really common i do get the headaches sometimes as well
and feeling exhausted even when you feel like you haven't actually done much so each of us really need to take the
time to write down and focus on what our own symptoms are when we start to get overwhelmed or start to get stressed
because that's when we know that we need to engage some of the things that we're going to talk about on the next slide to put things in reverse
and hopefully not hit burnout
and some of these things we talked about already because they're ongoing fundamental practices that help us build
resilience and understand ourselves better and that's the wellness wheel the emotional intelligence the brief framing
really important two of the things that lots of the research calls out as super important are relationships and
sleep getting enough sleep is super important for our mind and body regeneration
and having a support network of people that we can talk to and people that will listen to us is also essential for me another thing
um in terms of support network is counselling and coaches it's so sometimes it's
really nice just to have an external objective person to talk to and that can definitely be helpful taking regular
breaks as well i found is is more important than ever with the remote working i assume probably lots of people on here
are a remote working full-time i'm i'm in week i think 13 at this point
um pretty full-on so scheduling breaks in between meetings is really
important but also having annual leave which seems so weird booking annual leave when you can't go anywhere
um it just seems yeah seems silly but it's actually really really important that we still take
a break and take that chance to reset um especially you know going any more than three months without a proper break
is quite dangerous for our mental health i'm very excited to say that i have my first annual leave day booked
this friday first one in three months so it's definitely needed giving back has also
been shown to reduce stress and provide positive feelings to help prevent burnout so another one that i'm a fan of mentor
someone donate something i sent some cupcakes to the local chemist after they did my flu
shot a few weeks ago and it made me feel really happy to put a smile on someone else's face so
i'm a big fan of that and everything on this list is important um and also obviously everyone is
slightly different so pay attention to what works for you and what helps you de-stress i got
myself a piano drawing covert to learn piano and has been an amazing de-stressor for me even though it's been
challenging learning to play as well but i think because it uses some of the creative bits of my brain that i don't
get to use normally day to day at work it really helps me relax and it's been amazing
and just the last one i want to call out is practicing that's positive self-talk and being kind to
ourselves is something that um we don't focus on enough one of the
techniques that i use is to ask myself would i say that to someone else or would i speak like that to someone
else and often the answer is no because we're a lot harsher on ourselves than what we would ever be to someone
else a health psychologist named kelly
mcgonagall did a ted talk on how to make stress your friend sounds a bit crazy the talk explains how
neurohormone oxytocin which is also known as stress hormone works on our brains and our bodies it
enhances our empathy and motivates us to seek support and it relaxes our blood vessels during
stress and helps our hearts regenerate pretty powerful it also releases when we're supporting or caring for someone
else and the more stress the more that is released the healthier your stress
responses are and the faster you recover from stress so it's pretty powerful and i'll let you watch the ted talk
yourself once again i'll put it on there on the final slide but the spoiler is that the studies they
conducted showed that the belief of stress being bad for you indicated an increase of deaths of 43
over people who are experiencing the same amount of stress but they didn't share the belief that stress was bad for
you another study they did focusing on people with increased stress events in
their life such as financial strain or family crisis that increased their risk of dying by 30
percent showed that if they'd been caring for or helping others during this time they had a zero percent increase risk of
dying so um yeah pretty pretty exciting stats i think um so it's fairly
new on my radar but i think it makes sense to at least try to think about stress in a different way when i first started doing some public
speaking i um after a lifetime of being absolutely petrified of public speaking
it was suggested to me by someone that i reframe the feeling of nervousness into the feeling of excitement because it's
exactly the same feeling it's the same emotions and that worked really well so i figured this
stress thing could be something similar so i'm gonna give this one a try
we've spent a fair bit of time thinking about our minds and our bodies and understanding ourselves
in this puzzle is understanding what success and what good looks like for us and i'm talking about success across
life not just work because there's only one life so it's work-life integration not
work-life balance in my opinion so being crystal clear on what good looks like will enable you to achieve it
and everyone's different so for some it might be each year i want to have two family
holidays or i want to retire at a certain age i want to have a specific career
achievement i want to be recognised with an award it might be finding a life partner or
having children it might be to learn a language there's a billion different life designs but
figuring out what that picture of success and meaning looks like for you that you can work towards is really important
working smarter not harder is one of my favorite things to talk about because learning these techniques has definitely
saved me from burnout and has definitely reduced my stress levels
the first piece is understanding the difference between being productive and being efficient you can be super
efficient and get so much done in a day or a week and i've always prided myself on being very
efficient the great thing is the more efficient you are the more things you can fit into
your day or week or month so this will not stop you at all from being stressed or burning out
it will let you achieve maybe three times as much as your colleagues but it's not sustainable and if you're a
leader you don't have this choice anymore because you need to start working in another way through people productivity on the other
hand is what we're going to delve deeply into over the next slides
i'd like to if you could just ask yourself if you're good at multitasking for a moment i wonder if there's anybody
that that's good at multitasking i'm a woman so in theory i'm supposed to be great at multitasking right
wrong multitasking is not a thing we can only focus our attention on one
thing at a time and when we split our attention we can't process all the information
how many times we've been having a conversation with someone and you hear someone behind you having another conversation and you're like i really
want to i really want to hear what they're saying so you try and keep one ear on that conversation and one ear on this
conversation and all of a sudden they've asked you a question and you're like oh god i have no idea
what they just asked me multitasking fail so please let's just stop trying to
multitask being productive is focusing on just one thing at a time
one of my favorite things is if you fail to plan you're planning to fail in order to be productive you need to
understand what it is that you're trying to achieve you need to set goals that are tied to
achieving the overall strategy or vision and then break them down into long term so five to ten years uh medium term one
to three years and three and short term three to six month goals
now these goals i'm talking about life goals yes you're going to have some work goals in there as well but
goals in general for for everything um at some of your goals especially in that medium term one to three years
might be to keep doing what you're doing and that's fine but it's purposeful
for me personally i have some long-term goals around you know working less traveling more um then i have a lot of
short-term goals in for life and for work but a lot of my medium-term one to three year goals
are to keep doing what i'm doing because i found that i found that balance that i want for my life um and i'm happy for it to stay that way
for the next couple of years so goals goals are to be revisited
regularly every three to six months i would say do a check-in on how you're progressing against those goals
and change them if anything needs changing there's nothing wrong with changing direction i have i've pivoted my life and
career multiple times and there is nothing wrong with that
in order to be productive you want to be good in these four areas the first one is prioritizing so really
understanding the urgent versus important matrix we can get so caught up in that
never-ending inbox or the random questions from people and so much of it is not important and
not urgent while you're getting used to putting things in these categories just revert back to the matrix when you're
prioritizing your time if it's not important and it's not urgent then ideally you either want to
delegate it or consider not doing it at all procrastination is something i've always
been quite good at so this is something that you don't want to be good at um because it's not a good
thing i remember watching a ted talk once um while i wa about procrastinating while i was
procrastinating my university assignment not good so i know some people that set
their own imaginary deadlines for things to try and stop their procrastination but for me that's never worked because my brain knows that
it's not true so for me having clear goals and timelines set at quite a detailed level
is what helps the most to avoid procrastination and a couple of the the tips that we're going to talk about around
um structuring structuring our time as well on the next slides
big rocks refers to those strategic things and those big things that we want to work on or put time into
investigating more and they're generally in the not urgent but important box and they're the things
that always get pushed and pushed and pushed and not done if you haven't created the space for them and if you haven't
prioritized them but they're the things that really you know help you deliver results in your in your job or in your life so
really important to allocate the time and having clear goals and priorities
allows you to push back on things so when your boss asks you to do something ideally you want it to fit
into one of three categories either yes because i have capacity
either yes because yes but which of these priorities would you like me to push back or drop
in order to achieve this or yes i can do that within this number of days or this number of weeks
you always want your manager to know that you're there to help but you need to provide them visibility into your goals and priorities
so that they understand if you need to push back and they feel like they have some control over it
giving them this insight also prevents micromanagement from happening in my experience i've had a few micromanagers in my time
but the worst one i had um made me desperately want to quit my job and made me quite miserable however it
turned out that the job market was not very good at the time so i was kind of stuck
and you know it ends up being a good thing because it taught me a lot about how to deal with a micromanager
i was able to put some structure in place to give the manager the insight that he wanted and i reported back to him weekly on the
progress and within about three months which was a long three months he completely left me alone
and moved on to someone and moved on to micromanaging someone else i've been able to give him that
confidence that i had a clear plan clear goals and give him that feeling of control by giving those progress updates
with for him every week
assessing all of the time consuming and manual things that you do with the view to simplify them or make them repeatable
will also increase productivity one of the things that i found works really well is using email signature
templates so if you're getting a lot of similar types of questions that are coming from external people creating those email
signature templates as things that you can just quickly reply and send back to them is a really um
nice way to streamline for internal teams creating wikis or single sources of truth so that you can
point people to their own self-service option rather than relying on you all the time
and our inbox our inbox can be one of the biggest causes of stress and one of the most unproductive uses of our time
so ideally you want to action emails immediately by either responding deleting or moving
into a folder and if they build up and you end up with a giant inbox rather than let it stress you out just
face the facts that if you haven't gone back to something in a few weeks you're probably not going to and if it really is urgent someone's
going to follow up about it so consider deleting them or moving them into a when i get time
folder and you probably won't go back to them which means that they probably weren't urgent or
important can't care about everything so we need to admit that sometimes we
don't care enough to do something and that's because it's not a priority for us we put so much stress and
pressure on ourselves to care about everything but we can't make everything our priority and that's okay
when i used to see people from my team in the office after five pm i would go up to them and i would ask
them if anyone was going to die tomorrow tomorrow if they didn't if they didn't send this tonight is
anybody going to die if they didn't reply to something or get back to someone is anybody going to die
and the answer was always no no one is going to die if you don't stay at work late tonight
and finish sending this email or finish doing this task we need to stop putting so much pressure
on ourselves and sure if you're a medical professional then this is probably not a tip for you but
for the rest of us no one's going to die so once we're clear on our goals and priorities
we can then schedule our time to be most productive so using our calendar to block out
chunks block out and allocate chunks of time to strategic work to projects admin
emails and always making sure we're scheduling gaps in our calendar for the urgent and important things that might
come up each day generally something comes up at least once a day so if you've back to back
your entire calendar that's when you start having to work at night because you haven't left yourself
gaps during the day so really important and can one of the things that i've
implemented that has worked a charm is reducing the standard one-hour meeting like how often do
everything's a one hour meeting one hour one hour one hour reduce that down to 45 minutes you actually get the same amount done in
the meeting you hardly notice the difference it's slightly more efficient but it creates at least this minimum 15
minute gap for you if you do ever have to back-to-back meetings and just having that headspace of that 15 minutes especially working
remotely to go and get a cup of tea or just have a little bit of a break makes a huge difference
beware of meetings in general though don't accept meetings if you don't need to be in them and like we talked about earlier push
back if there's no value in it also push for any meetings to have a clear agenda and request that people
prep before the meeting i read a really great book i read by michael hyatt called free
to focus had some amazing tips about productivity and the one that i've implemented was around purposefully
scheduling my week into external days internal days and strategic days and i
was telling one of my colleagues about it and she was saying to me she was really concerned
she was saying like surely you have to be flexible for your customers like how does that work for your customers
but what i said to her is that most of the time if you give customers some options they'll find an option that
will fit as long as you're purposeful so if i'm purposeful about saying tuesdays and thursdays are my external meeting days
99 of my customers are gonna say yeah no problem that works for me i can stick that in
um but it's when you're not purposeful that you end up with crazy days doing all sorts of different things context
shifting all the time and it's really hard to be productive and what i found is that structuring my
week like that made me so much more productive because i was able to focus get into that flow
state and get through stuff much faster and i always had time for those big rocks and strategic things
that what really ensured my success i'm also a big fan of running with a
a daily to-do list as well but that could be my achiever personality needing to tick things off off my list but more specifically each
day and week really knowing what are the three things that equal success so this week
or this day if all i get done is three things what are those three things and being and these three things
obviously come from your short-term goals that you've set yourself but doing that takes off so much stress
and pressure makes you feel more like you're you know succeeding and ticking the boxes and
achieving but also it's what allows you to continue to deliver results for towards those goals
it's a huge shift when you move into a team lead or manager role and have to start delivering through others instead of on your own
and it becomes about motivating others and it's such a different type of noise often a lot more noisy all of the
questions all of the time it feels like everybody wants a piece of you
and at the end of the day or the week you often look around and you're like what did i even achieve
this week it can feel super reactive and it can be really hard to feel successful
my biggest tip in dealing with people asking you questions is don't answer the question
and that may sound harsh but hear me out 95 percent of the time the person either
already knows the answer or they can figure out the answer if you ask them some probing questions
and help them if you give people the answers all the time straight away they will just keep coming back to you and the noise will
just increase and increase and increase but if you help them understand how to problem problem-solve
themselves and how to think through it and solve it themselves they will be much they won't come to you
as much and they'll also be able to help other people around them do the same thing and the amount of noise that goes away
when you do that over a long period is amazing
the other thing that will give you so much time back as a leader is empowering your team not delegating
to them in my last role i had 80 direct reports mostly developers
it was pretty full on so bringing together the senior people across the team
to share with them the strategy and the vision or create that with them if it's a smaller organization and that you
don't have that yet is the first thing that you need to do and then working with those
with those people to come up with the goals to make sure that they're agreed goals within the team
and then once those goals are agreed really giving complete ownership and empowerment of individual goals to
specific members within the team and then let them go and involve the wider teams
to deliver those goals however they want give them that full empowerment to deliver
because they're you know they're all different as well they're going to have different strengths they're going to want to deliver in different ways so let
them make sure that you set any expectations of any progress updates or timelines or
reporting that they need to be aware of because that's that's important um but also make sure that you know that they know that
you're there to support them or to remove any blockers that they come up against so you want to make sure that
that you're there that they know that you're there and that you've got their back dan pink's book drive is one of my
favorites on why autonomy mastery and purpose is so important for people definitely worth a read if you haven't
already and we talked about identifying our own
superpowers well it's exactly the same for your team if they're doing what they're good at they'll be more productive and more
engaged and as a leader you want to form your teams based on these strengths where possible sometimes you don't get a choice to put
a team together but if you are forming a team think about what are the different hats or roles
that are required for this goal or this project in this team and then bring people in for their
strengths so you might need somebody who who really enjoys or who's good at stakeholder management you might need
somebody who is good at is a good team leader you might need someone who's an excellent
technical mentor you might need someone who's a great front-end developer or back-end developer because we know
they're not the same person right but really think about what those hats are and roles are
and then bring people in that have those strengths because they're going to be much better at it and they're going to have a lot more fun doing it
also when you're recruiting new members into your team you need to look at exactly the same thing so what are the strengths gaps
within your team and then look for people that have those particular strengths diversity in your team will make it a
lot more successful and a lot more fun
as a leader your life is also much easier if you have an engaged team so empowering them giving them autonomy
giving them insight into the strategy and vision which we've talked about will play a huge part in engagement
but also the purpose and mastery piece is really engaged by creating a team
culture that's built on shared values if you're gonna if your organization already has shared values
or values then break them down and make sure that they're meaningful for your team but if they don't then work with your
team and create these values together you can make them core values or
principles at amazon we have leadership principles and then we also create team tenants as
well which helps us define what good looks like for our team and what behaviours we reward providing
flexibility and choice are two of the other key things that you can provide to your team to keep them engaged
we talked about earlier the worst thing that you can be as a micro manager um no exaggeration i have interviewed
thousands of people over the years and nearly 80 percent of them the reason
that they give for leaving their job was their manager so we don't want to be one of those managers
and the other important piece of that strong team culture is is celebrating success and celebrating
small wins so ideally you want to tie a reward and recognition program to the values because it will help drive
the culture and the behaviors that you want to see within the team that's what my startup shout out is all
about so it's enabling peer-to-peer recognition which is really important but then also tying that into management
recognition through an awards program and this stuff doesn't need to be expensive if you're looking for ideas on

the business coach i was working with at the time said to me wow i'm not sure i've ever had someone
get a zero on this and at the time i was wondering why my staff turnover was so high
it probably took me close to five to get it to build it and practice and get it to a decent level
but now empathy is one of my highest results when i do these tests and more importantly i've learned to
really enjoy it and it has turned into one of my strengths empathy is not sympathy
it's just taking the time to listen and understand people and see and feel things from their perspective when combined with a high

the time to remind everyone in these worrisome times that everything's going to be okay

it's also our role to provide regular feedback to the individuals in our team and we touched on that earlier that many

feedback is seven to one in order for people to actually take on board the positive
feedback and to retain it and not just listen to that one piece of negative feedback

constructive feedback needs to be immediate objective and really clear nip it in the bud is

we all work hard and uh super busy so part of us having a sustainable and enjoyable life is experiencing success

enjoy our life starting with comparison being the root
of all evil it absolutely destroys people and i'm sure that we've all have friends that
are taking a break from social media because they can't cope with it anymore and often the reason is because they
can't help but look at all these people's perfect posts and perfect pictures and compare their own lives to
theirs why do we do this who cares what other people are doing well it's human nature in our society to

this can help us stop the comparison behavior because we have our own clear picture and clear focus of what we want
our life to look like practicing gratitude is another thing that helps being appreciative of what we
have in our lives regardless if we where we're at in achieving our goals
and reframing as well is quite a handy tip um this picture of the boat is amazing
and you know if this was one of my friends on facebook that posted this you know just bought me a boat
would i get a little pang of jelly sure i would um but then i'd reframe it and

actually i'd rather hire a boat because i probably only want to do that you know every a few times a

looks like picture i can and it kind of takes away that comparison thing because you know what i

so um true story i do have hiring a bow quarterly on my what good looks like
picture because i do love a good boat party so we are all we all have control over whether we focus on ourselves
and enjoy our life or whether we are always looking at other people and comparing ourselves

out of my brains so the meditation type of mindfulness is not for everyone
if it is for you then good on you because it's very good for you but it's definitely not for everyone so
and i've tried i have tried i've practiced and i've tried it doesn't work for me so for me mindfulness is about appreciation and
moments it's really easy to soak up every single moment of our time with busyness and
distractions and all of the technology so mindfulness for me is stopping to take a breath a
few times a day and just taking a moment to appreciate our surroundings
so some days that might be you know i'm sitting in the office and i just take a moment to breathe
and to look around the room and you know look at my awesome colleagues and be
like oh man i'm so lucky to work with these awesome people and you know i'm just so i'm just
so glad that i work here i'm really really happy right now um or it might be when i'm going to buy
my lunch one day and i'm walking down the street to buy lunch and i just take a moment and i look up
at the clouds and they're just beautiful and i look around at some of the trees and i think to myself
man i love living in perth like it's so beautiful so it's just about remembering who you
are where you are and why you are and it's amazing how doing something so simple
can help clear your mind and help you focus on the rest of your day and help bring that calmness back into
our lives and that appreciation
mark manson has a couple of awesome books um and talks about how our brains work and how they need to
solve problems and if you solve all the problems in your life your brain will actually create more problems for you to solve
and some of those might be problems you don't want so i don't know whether anyone else has experienced this but i have
blown up my life a couple of times when things were going too well and were too calm and i solved the problems and my brain
my brain created more brain that's a new one so this is not what you want
thankfully i've learned this lesson and now i make sure that my life has plenty of the problems that i love to solve
and i'm not striving to get rid of all the problems anymore because i know that my brain needs these problems in my life
so if you haven't read the book definitely recommend reading it and making sure that you know what kind
of problems you love solving
achievement is addictive and i can say firsthand that being an achievement addict is exhausting because you always think
you'll be happy successful once you climb one mountain but you get to the top and there's another one to climb
and there's always something more to achieve if you pin your happiness or success to achievement and being an achievement addict is a
definite path to burnout some things that i found can help with this is reframing what achievement is
so for me not working for a whole weekend is an achievement that i celebrate
i'm choosing to chill out and watch tv at the end of the day is an achievement and while i may not be
able to completely switch off the drive to achieve i can still focus it on what behave on the behaviors of what good looks like
in the life picture that i'm trying to achieve celebrating and seeing achievement as
smashing out the work goals that you set for the week or hitting the savings goal that you set
for the month or going on a family holiday or taking a day off to go hang out with your family really
tailor these to suit what's important to you and acknowledge that you don't have to be on all the time
and make sure that you reward yourself for choosing to turn off
i really love this quote because um you know a lot of a lot of what we've talked about today is making sure that we don't

so summing up summing up if i had to to narrow this down to a few key points
it would be the following eight um put yourself first you can't help
anyone else if you're stressed or burnt out and remember your wellness wheel very important
the second productivity over efficiency being efficient can often mean working harder and longer being
productive means being smart simplifying and prioritizing like a pro
empower over delegate delegation gives you short-term capacity empowerment gives you long-term capacity
and a much happier team what good looks like figuring out what success looks like for you set your
short medium and long-term goals based on this mindfulness moments each day to enjoy
your success and capture gratefulness beware the comparison trap
reframe what achievement means to you and finally keep calm the calmest person
in the room has the advantage because they can see the full picture
